summary: This is an email forwarding a Washington Post opinion article criticizing the use of non-disclosure agreements (NDAs) to silence victims in the Jeffrey Epstein case. The article argues that secret settlements enable wealthy predators like Epstein to avoid accountability and calls for legal reform to prevent NDAs from concealing evidence of crimes.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Represents two alleged Epstein victims bound by NDAs; argues that agreements to conceal evidence of a crime should not be enforceable.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Credibly accused of sexually assaulting dozens of underage girls; used his wealth to secure secret settlements with victims.

persons.name: Kenneth A. Marra
persons.context: Ruled that federal prosecutors, led by Alexander Acosta, broke the law by entering a secret plea deal with Epstein.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.role: U.S. Labor Secretary (at the time), former U.S. Attorney
persons.context: Led federal prosecutors who entered a secret plea deal with Epstein, which Judge Marra ruled broke the law.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Mentioned as part of Epstein's circle of friends.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned as part of Epstein's circle of friends.

persons.name: Kevin Spacey
persons.context: Mentioned as part of Epstein's circle of friends.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned as part of Epstein's circle of friends.

persons.name: Harvey Weinstein
persons.context: Cited as another example of a powerful man using NDAs to hide evidence of sexual assault.

persons.name: Leslie Moonves
persons.context: Cited as another example of a powerful man using NDAs to hide evidence of sexual assault or harassment.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Battling to keep details of her settlement with an Epstein accuser sealed from public view in a New York appeals court.

persons.name: Jose A. Cabranes
persons.role: Judge, U.S. Court of Appeals for the 2nd Circuit
persons.context: Openly scoffed at Maxwell's attorney during a March hearing arguing for secrecy regarding her settlement.

connections.description: Boies represents alleged victims of Epstein who are bound by NDAs with Epstein.
Maxwell is described as an Epstein friend and confidante.
Acosta, as a federal prosecutor, led the team that entered a secret plea deal with Epstein.
Judge Cabranes presided over a hearing where Maxwell's attorney argued to keep a settlement sealed.

events.title: Judge Marra's ruling on Epstein plea deal
events.description: U.S. District Judge Kenneth A. Marra ruled that federal prosecutors led by Alexander Acosta broke the law by entering a secret plea deal with Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Appeals court hearing on Maxwell settlement
events.description: Hearing at the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 2nd Circuit where Judge Jose A. Cabranes scoffed at arguments by Ghislaine Maxwell's attorney to keep her settlement with an Epstein accuser sealed.

keyFacts: Attorney David Boies states that 'dozens' of women who could testify about being sexually assaulted by Jeffrey Epstein are silenced by non-disclosure agreements (NDAs).
Judge Kenneth A. Marra ruled that federal prosecutors, led by then-Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta, broke the law with a secret plea deal that allowed Epstein to serve a lenient sentence.
The article argues that NDAs used to conceal evidence of crimes are a form of 'rich man's justice' that undermines public accountability.
Ghislaine Maxwell is fighting in a New York appeals court to keep details of her settlement with an Epstein accuser sealed from public view.
The article calls for a legal change to make agreements that conceal evidence of a crime unenforceable and for investigations into Epstein's conduct in New York, New Mexico, and the Virgin Islands.
